Description

A simple representation of relation types based on C.J. Date, "An Introduction to Database Systems" Eighth Edition.

The representation of Relvar is based on Sets, where each relation tuple is of the type Row, or a synonym for Set (String, Elem). Elem is an Algebraic Data Type representing each tuple's element.

Re-export

data TypeRep :: *

A concrete representation of a (monomorphic) type. TypeRep supports reasonably efficient equality.

Instances

Ord TypeRep 
Show TypeRep 

Types

data Elem Source

Type for Relvar's elements. Elem types are either primitive types or Relvars or array of Elems or tuple of Elems (2 and 3 arguments). One can extend the primitive types by adding to the code's definitions (look for "-- ADD NEW TYPES HERE" comments in code).

T Text

BS ByteString 
A [Elem]

array of Elems

T2 (Elem, Elem)

pair of Elems

T3 (Elem, Elem, Elem)

triplet of Elems

R Relvar

relation

DW (Down Elem)

convenient for ordering Elems in descending order

type Attributes = LSet TypeRep Source

Attributes is the type synonym for LSet TypeRep, i.e. for Set (String, TypeRep). The LSet type enforces that there are no blank label, nor any duplicate labels.

type Row = LSet Elem Source

Row is synonym for LSet Elem, i.e. for Set (String, Elem). The LSet type enforces that there are no blank label, nor any duplicate label.

data Relvar Source

Relvar is the type for relations. A relation is defined by the set of its attributes (i.e. labels' names and types) and of its tuples, or rows, (i.e. sets of Elems). There is unicity of Attributes labels and no two rows can be identical.

See C.J. Date, "An Introduction to Database Systems" Eighth Edition, chapter 6 ('Relations').

Constructors

Relvar 

Fields

attributes :: Attributes

Set of the relation's attributes.

rdata :: Set Row

Set of the relation's tuples (i.e. rows).

data Table Source

Type for tables. A relation's table output is mostly for representation. Unlike relations, tables can have duplicate rows and column headers. See full difference between relations and tables in C.J. Date, "An Introduction to Database Systems" Eighth Edition, chapter 6 ('Relations').

data ColOrder Source

ADT for selecting sorting in ascending or descending orders.

Construction

relvar :: [String] -> [TypeRep] -> [[Elem]] -> Relvar Source

Create a relation variable provided its Attributes' labels and types (i.e. column names and types) and its Row elements.

dee :: Relvar Source

Constant relation with an empty set of attributes and 1-tuple (equal to the empty set) body ([C.J. Date] chap. 6).

dee = Relvar {attributes= Set.empty, rdata = Set.singleton $ Set.empty}.

dum :: Relvar Source

Constant relation with an empty set of attributes and no-tuple body ([C.J. Date] chap. 6).

dum = Relvar {attributes= Set.empty, rdata = Set.empty}.

rename :: LabelOp a => a -> [String] -> [String] -> a Source

Replace LSet's labels. For Relvars, rename its Attributes's labels.

Query

Information

degree :: LabelOp a => a -> Int Source

Return the number of elements in the set. For Relvars, return its Attributes's size (e.g. its number of columns).

card :: Relvar -> Int Source

Cardinality of a relation (i.e. # of tuples or # of rows).

elems :: Relvar -> [[(String, Elem)]] Source

Extract all elements.

elems' :: Relvar -> Bool -> [String] -> [[Elem]] Source

Extract elements given labels.

labels :: LabelOp a => a -> [String] Source

Return LSet's labels. For Relvars, return its Attributes's labels.

types :: Relvar -> [TypeRep] Source

Return the all Attributes' types.

types' :: Relvar -> Bool -> [String] -> [TypeRep] Source

Return Attributes' types for the matching labels.

common :: Relvar -> Relvar -> Attributes Source

Common attributes

Logical

compatible :: (LabelOp a, Ord a, Show a) => a -> a -> Bool Source

Check that two LSets or two Relvars are "compatible", e.g. there is no label equality without value equality. For Relvars, True if their Attributes are compatible.

match :: (LabelOp a, Eq a) => a -> a -> Bool Source

LSets equality. For Relvars, True if the Attributes of two relations are equal.

disjoint :: (LabelOp a, Ord a) => a -> a -> Bool Source

True if LSets are compatible and disjoint.

Table

table :: Relvar -> Maybe [String] -> Maybe [(String, ColOrder)] -> Maybe [Int] -> Table Source

Output a table given a set of labels, a row indexing function and a list of row indices.

If lbls is Nothing all relation labels are included (in default order). If the row indices argument is nothing, all rows are included.

Label functions

keepLeft :: Relvar -> [String] -> [String] Source

Given a relation and some of its labels [ai0, ai1, ... ain], returns the relation's attributes reordered with lftlbls on the left and then the remaining labels from lbls.

keepRight :: Relvar -> [String] -> [String] Source

Given a relation and some of its labels [ai0, ai1, ... ain], returns the relation's attributes reordered with lftlbls on the left and then the remaining labels from lbls.
